title: How to factor with three variables - Quora

response.answer_text: 9a^2 + 4bc - 4c^2 - b^2   I would rewrite it as  9a^2 - b^2 + 4bc -4c^2  then isolate a polynomial.  9a^2 - (b^2 - 4bc + 4c^2)    The signs change when you subtract in the parentheses.  Then factor the polynomial  9a^2 - (b - 2c)^2.  Note that this polynomial is the difference of two squares, so it  is in the form y^2 - z^2 where  y = 3a and z = b - 2c.   We know that we can factor the difference of two squares as  follows:   y^2 - z^2 = (y-z)(y+z)  Therefore we get   (3a - (b - 2c))(3a + (b - 2c))  as our finished answer.
